byline.contributor: Diaa Hadid reported from Ramallah, and Anne Barnard from Beirut, Lebanon. Reporting was contributed by Hwaida Saad from Beirut, and an employee of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria.
byline.original: By DIAA HADID and ANNE BARNARD

abstract: Hezbollah Commander Samir Kuntar, released by Israeli authorities in controversial prisoner exchange in 2008, dies after missiles hits building in Jaramana neighborhood of Damascus; Kuntar, who spent 30 years in Israeli prison for role in 1979 killings, was in Syria as part military campaign aiding Pres Bashar al-Assad; Farhan al-Sha’alan, leader of Hezbollah affiliate Syrian Resistance, also died in attack
lead_paragraph: The killing of Samir Kuntar, in a government-held neighborhood of Damascus, underscored the complexity of Syria’s civil war and the long arms of its many players.

headline.main: Commander of Hezbollah Freed by Israel Is Killed in Syria
headline.print_headline: Commander of Hezbollah Freed by Israel Dies in Syria

snippet: The killing of Samir Kuntar, in a government-held neighborhood of Damascus, underscored the complexity of Syria’s civil war and the long arms of its many players.
